dt: {bc}a phenomenon of light (such as red, brown, pink, or gray) or visual perception that enables one to differentiate otherwise identical objects

dt.t: movies in {wi}color{/wi}

dt.t: … the USSR changed neither its {wi}colors{/wi} nor its stripes during all of this …

dt.t: … that {wi}color{/wi} and force of style which were later to make him outstanding among American editors …
The play had a good deal of {wi}color{/wi} to it.

{bc}a {d_link|hypothetical|hypothetical} property of {d_link|quarks|quark} that differentiates each type into three forms having a distinct role in binding quarks together

et: Middle English {it}colour,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, going back to Latin {it}color,{/it} earlier {it}colōs{/it} "color as a physical phenomenon, pigment, complexion, appearance," probably, assuming an original meaning "covering, outermost layer, appearance," going back to {it}*ḱel-ōs,{/it} collective derivative from an Indo-European s-stem {it}*ḱel-os{/it} "covering" (whence perhaps Sanskrit {it}śaras-{/it} "skin on boiled milk, cream" and, from a thematic derivative, Old High German {it}hulisa{/it} "hull of a legume"), derivative of a verbal base {it}*ḱel-{/it} "cover, conceal" {ma}{mat|conceal|conceal}{/ma}
shortdef: a phenomenon of light (such as red, brown, pink, or gray) or visual perception that enables one to differentiate otherwise identical objects

the aspect of the appearance of objects and light sources that may be described in terms of hue, lightness, and saturation for objects and hue, brightness, and saturation for light sources; also : a specific combination of hue, saturation, and lightness or brightness
a color other than and as contrasted with black, white, or gray

dt: {bc}to change the color of (as by dyeing, staining, or painting)

dt.t: She {wi}colors{/wi} her hair.

dt: {bc}to change as if by dyeing or painting: such as

dt.t: "The lives of most of us have been {wi}colored{/wi} by politics … "
a highly {wi}colored{/wi} version of the facts
{wi}color{/wi} a lie
… call it progress; {wi}color{/wi} it inevitable with shades of job security

dt: {bc}to fill in a shape or picture outlined on a piece of paper using markers, crayons, colored pencils, etc.

dt.t: His granddaughter Fernanda sat at his side, {wi}coloring{/wi} with crayons.
She {wi}colored{/wi} at the mention of his name.

et: Middle English {it}colouren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}colurer,{/it} going back to Latin {it}colōrāre,{/it} derivative of {it}color{/it} {et_link|color:1|color:1}
shortdef: to change the color of (as by dyeing, staining, or painting)
to change as if by dyeing or painting: such as

dt: {bc}to show what one is really like {bc}to reveal one's real nature or character

dt.t: He seemed nice at first, but he {it}showed his true colors{/it} during the crisis.

shortdef: to show what one is really like : to reveal one's real nature or character

dt: {bc}color in an image (such as a photograph) of an object that does not actually appear in the object but is used to enhance, contrast, or distinguish details

shortdef: color in an image (such as a photograph) of an object that does not actually appear in the object but is used to enhance, contrast, or distinguish details

a {wi}flying{/wi} leap

dt.t: a {wi}flying{/wi} club

dt.t: a {wi}flying{/wi} kilometer

shortdef: moving or capable of moving in the air
moving or made by moving rapidly

dt: {bc}the presentation of the features and peculiarities of a particular locality and its inhabitants in writing

shortdef: the presentation of the features and peculiarities of a particular locality and its inhabitants in writing
a pigment used for oil paint

dt: {bc}having a predominant color broken by patches of one or more other colors

et: obsolete English {it}party{/it} parti-color, from Middle English {it}parti{/it}, from Anglo-French, of two colors, from past participle of {it}partir{/it} to divide
shortdef: showing different colors or tints; especially : having a predominant color broken by patches of one or more other colors

shortdef: an opaque watercolor paint with a gum- or glue-size binder sold usually in jars —called also poster paint
